items.title: US Securities Regulator Drops Coinbase Lawsuit
items.summary:
- The US SEC is withdrawing its lawsuit against Coinbase, ending a legal conflict that started in 2023.
- The lawsuit claimed Coinbase allowed trading in 13 crypto tokens that should be registered as securities and questioned its staking program compliance.
- Coinbase argued that crypto assets don't meet the legal definition of securities.
- The SEC's withdrawal indicates a shift in its cryptocurrency regulation strategy under current leadership, which includes reorganizing the crypto enforcement unit and creating an industry task force.

items.title: European tech sector surges in Q4, led by ASML, Nokia
items.summary:
- The European technology sector's earnings rose 5.5% in Q4, surpassing the 0.5% forecast.
- ASML reported strong bookings that doubled analyst expectations, spurred by AI investments.
- Nokia experienced improvements in its 5G units and anticipates increased data center demand.
- STMicroelectronics and Infineon faced struggles due to weak automotive demand and limited AI engagement.
- SAP reported a 29% increase in cloud backlog and raised its 2025 revenue forecast.
- Analysts caution about risks including potential US tariffs and economic challenges in Europe and China.

items.title: BYD Korea has no plans to sell DeepSeek-integrated cars
items.summary:
- BYD Korea will not market vehicles equipped with DeepSeek’s AI software in South Korea due to data security concerns.
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI firm, has faced restrictions in South Korea over potential data leaks to China.
- BYD's AI-integrated models are designated only for the Chinese market, and BYD Korea will comply with local regulations.
- Personal data collected in South Korea will remain secure and won't be transferred to China.
- BYD Korea has successfully launched the Atto 3 electric SUV, which does not include DeepSeek’s technology.

items.title: Capital SEA: Southeast Asia’s funding landscape
items.author: Yeo Cheng Yong, Terence Lee
items.summary:
- The article analyzes the funding landscape in Southeast Asia, addressing investor activity and funding trends.
- It consists of two sections: **Weekly Update**, which highlights recent investor activity, and **Macro Trends**, showcasing country-wide funding distributions.
- Access to detailed data requires a subscription, indicating premium content availability.

items.title: BMW reviews UK Mini EV production timeline
Fintech giants expand services despite stock volatility
items.summary:
- The fintech sector is seeing convergence as Block, Affirm, and PayPal expand services.
- Block missed earnings estimates, resulting in an 18% stock drop, but is integrating new services through Afterpay acquisition.
- Affirm exceeded earnings expectations with a 22% stock surge, reporting US$10.1 billion in gross merchandise volume.
- Affirm's active users grew by 23%, and the Affirm Card user base increased by 136% year-over-year.
- PayPal reported US$437.8 billion in total payment volume, focusing on Venmo for merchant transactions to compete with Apple Pay and Shop Pay.

items.title: Tencent reshuffle AI apps as competition heats up
items.summary:
- Tencent reorganizes several AI applications into its Cloud & Smart Industries Group (CSIG) due to rising competition.
- Affected apps include QQ Browser, Sogou Pinyin keyboard, and learning assistant Ima, originally under the Platform & Content Group.
- The AI chatbot Yuanbao was also moved to CSIG from the Technology Engineering Group.
- The restructuring was confirmed by a Tencent representative on February 21, focusing on integrating AI into practical applications and enhancing monetization.
- Analyst Zhang Yi notes this shift aims to refine product experience and leverage user feedback amid competition from rivals like Alibaba and Baidu.

items.title: Xpeng expands to 60 markets by 2025
items.summary:
- Xpeng plans to expand its international markets from 30 to 60 by the end of 2025, as announced by CEO He Xiaopeng on Feb. 22.
- The company has started its first global shipment of the X9, sending 300 right-hand drive units to Thailand.
- Currently, only the G6 model is available in Thailand, with more models to be introduced.
- Xpeng is enhancing its charging infrastructure with ultra-fast charging stations set for Thailand and Hong Kong by early 2025.
- The company will begin testing its autonomous driving system in international markets this year, with a goal for self-driving vehicles by 2026.
- Xpeng's 'go-global 2.0 strategy' will include markets in the Middle East and Africa, in addition to Europe and Southeast Asia.
- International sales accounted for 13% of total sales in 2024, aiming to reach 50% by 2027.

items.title: Indian furniture retailer Pepperfry’s revenue drops 31% in FY24
items.summary:
- Pepperfry reported a 31% drop in operational revenue for FY24, falling to ₹188.9 crore (US$21.8 million).
- Total income decreased by 28% year-on-year to ₹209.2 crore (US$24.14 million).
- Net loss narrowed by 37.4% to ₹117.5 crore (US$13.56 million), and EBITDA loss decreased by 52.2% to ₹43.6 crore (US$5.03 million).
- Total expenditures dropped 31.1% to ₹326.7 crore (US$37.70 million).
- Employee expenses were cut by 29.7%, and marketing costs were reduced by nearly 45%.
- Founded in 2012, Pepperfry operates in 173 cities with over 200 studios.
- The company has raised over US$305 million, and announced plans for an IPO were shelved in 2024 amid stagnant sales.
- Originally aiming for 10-15% revenue growth in FY25, the path to profitability remains uncertain.

items.title: Court filings reveal Meta staff debated copyrighted content
items.summary:
- Unsealed court documents in the Kadrey v. Meta case disclose that Meta employees discussed the use of copyrighted content to train AI models.
- A research engineer suggested purchasing e-books at retail prices for speed, despite legal concerns.
- Meta considered using Libgen for accessing copyrighted books and debated how to avoid public acknowledgment of such actions.
- Some insiders at Meta argued that existing data from Facebook and Instagram might not suffice for advanced AI training, driving a push for more extensive datasets, even against previous decisions regarding copyrighted content.
- The Kadrey v. Meta case, initiated in 2023 in California, accuses Meta of analyzing both pirated and licensed books for potential licensing negotiations.

items.title: OpenAI to shift 75% of data centers to Stargate by 2030
items.summary:
- OpenAI plans to move 75% of its data centers to the Stargate infrastructure by 2030.
- This shift aims to enhance efficiency and reduce operational costs.
- The transition is part of OpenAI's broader strategy to optimize its cloud computing resources.

items.title: NetEase cuts jobs, projects as growth remains slow
items.summary:
- NetEase Inc. is undergoing major restructuring, led by CEO William Ding, involving significant job cuts and project halts.
- The company is canceling around a dozen games and shutting down international studios including Ouka, Worlds Untold, and Jar of Sparks, affecting fewer than 60 employees.
- New investments in gaming studios and IPs have been paused since early 2024, alongside a reduced global investment team.
- Despite a 1.5% revenue growth in gaming, gross profit declined by 2.6%, with overall growth slow at single-digit increases in the past two years.
- The game Marvel Rivals generated over US$200 million and attracted more than 40 million users since December.

items.title: Uber CEO says Tesla rejects partnership for robotaxi plans
items.summary:
- Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi confirmed Tesla will launch its robotaxi service independently.
- Discussions between Uber and Tesla CEO Elon Musk ended with Tesla choosing a solo strategy.
- Tesla's decision makes it a competitor to Uber and Waymo, which plans to launch autonomous rides in Austin next month.
- Uber has formed over 12 partnerships with self-driving firms since 2023, but Tesla will not integrate with Uber's platform.
- Khosrowshahi expressed hope that Tesla's participation could stabilize demand in the autonomous vehicle market.

items.title: ByteDance valued over $400b by major investors
items.summary:
- ByteDance has been valued at over US$400 billion by major investors, recovering from a low of US$275 billion in mid-2022.
- Valuations included US$410 billion by Fidelity Investments and US$450 billion by T. Rowe Price Group.
- Estimates based on SEC filings exclude TikTok's US operations due to ongoing ban concerns.
- The increase in valuation is driven by strong revenue growth and the potential of its AI chatbot, Doubao, which has 75 million active users.
- Recovery of China's tech sector, aided by AI advancements and regulatory easing, contributed to the rise.

items.title: Asia’s tech investors with the highest exit rates
items.summary:
- The article provides insights on tech investors in Asia known for high exit rates.
- Exits can occur through mergers, secondary sales, or public listings, but high exit rates signal only partial success.
- Later-stage investors often have better exit rates due to lower risk and higher liquidity in their investments.
- A strong local market can facilitate exits for startups in certain countries.
- The article hints that some investors listed may be outperforming expectations in their exit strategies.
- Readers can access additional data through linked charts and a database of companies.

items.title: If you build it, will they come?
items.summary:
- Neolix, an autonomous vehicle company in Beijing, raised US$137 million in a series C round.
- Dream, an AI security firm from Israel, raised US$100 million in series B funding.
- Indian B2B ecommerce firm Udaan secured US$75 million in funding from existing investors.
- Healing Paper from South Korea raised nearly US$30 million in series C funding.
- Japanese salon company Salowin obtained almost US$18 million in debt financing.

items.title: These are the most active investors in Japan’s startups
items.summary:
- The article lists the most active investors in Japan’s startups over the past two years.
- Investors are ranked by the number of deals made with Japan-based startups.
- Only firms that have invested in three or more companies in Japan within the last 12 months are featured.

items.title: Alibaba makes artificial general intelligence its focus
items.summary:
- Alibaba CEO Eddie Wu announces focus on artificial general intelligence (AGI).
- Enhancing intelligence models is key to Alibaba's long-term vision towards AI.
- Company declares itself an AI-driven entity while maintaining e-commerce as a central focus.
- Alibaba's cloud services revenue rose 13% last quarter, with AI-related products seeing triple-digit growth.
- Plans to significantly increase investment in cloud and AI infrastructure over the next three years.
- Alibaba's US shares rose 11% in premarket trading following the announcement.

items.title: YouTube introduces ‘premium lite’ for ad-free videos
items.summary:
- YouTube launches ‘premium lite,’ a lower-cost tier for ad-free access to podcasts and non-music videos.
- Rolling out in the US, Australia, Germany, and Thailand, this tier allows ads in music videos unlike the higher-priced YouTube Premium plan.
- The offering aims to provide users more flexibility and was previously tested in select markets; pricing and release date are undisclosed.
- The launch responds to increasing competition in video and podcast markets, impacting YouTube creators' revenue as platforms like Spotify explore monetization strategies.

items.title: Suzuki shifts to hybrids, cuts EV plans
items.summary:
- Suzuki Motor is reducing investment in new EVs and focusing more on hybrids due to declining demand in India and Europe.
- Planned EV models for India cut from 6 to 4, and for Europe from 5 to 4 by fiscal 2030.
- The company aims for annual sales of 8 trillion yen (US$53 billion) by fiscal 2030, enhancing hybrid production instead.
- In India, Suzuki plans to boost natural gas vehicle sales and expand local production for exports.
- This strategy follows broader industry trends, with other automakers like Honda and Subaru increasing their hybrid commitments.

items.title: Japan looks to Vietnam for semiconductor talent
items.summary:
- Japanese semiconductor manufacturers are seeking talent in Vietnam to address labor shortages.
- A delegation from Japan's Kyushu region visited Hanoi to discuss hiring opportunities with local IT companies and universities.
- Vietnamese engineers possess basic training, beneficial for business expansion in the semiconductor sector.
- Vietnam's population is 100 million, with a median age in the early thirties, offering a strong talent pool.
- The Vietnamese government aims to train 50,000 semiconductor workers by 2030.
- Vietnam is also attracting attention from other tech giants, such as Samsung and Nvidia, which are expanding in the country.

items.title: A list of fundraising startups from Asia and beyond (Updated)
items.summary:
- Fundraising is challenging, leading to the compilation of a list of fundraising startups.
- Startups can sign up to be listed and get exposure to investors.
- Investors can opt-in to receive information about curated fundraising startups through subscription.

items.title: Dubai to launch first driverless taxis by early 2026
items.author: Mansoor Alfalasi
items.summary:
- Dubai Taxi Company (DTC) plans to launch its first driverless taxi service by early 2026.
- The initiative aims to address regulatory, safety, and operational needs in collaboration with the Roads and Transport Authority (RTA).
- Testing will begin in early 2026, with initial deployment areas to be selected by the RTA.
- Dubai has commenced advancements in autonomous mobility with supervised testing starting in 2023, and plans to introduce electric air taxis as well.
- Abu Dhabi already has operational driverless taxis, with a commercial service launched on Yas Island by Uber and WeRide in December.
- DTC expanded its fleet by 744 vehicles last year, reaching a total of 5,960, with further expansion planned for 2025.

items.title: Bybit hit by largest crypto heist, loses $1.5b
items.summary:
- Bybit experienced a security breach leading to the theft of $1.5 billion in digital assets, marking the largest crypto heist in history.
- Hackers targeted the exchange's cold wallet, and funds were primarily in ether.
- The stolen funds were moved through multiple wallets before being liquidated.
- This breach surpasses the previous notable hacks including Poly Network ($611 million) and Binance ($570 million).
- The perpetrators were identified as North Korea's Lazarus Group, known for targeting crypto platforms since 2017.
- Bybit's CEO Ben Zhou confirmed the security of other cold wallets and that withdrawals continue normally.
- Bybit secured a bridge loan from undisclosed partners to cover the losses.

items.title: Open Source AI Foundation launches $10m advocacy push
items.author: Brittany Kaiser, Joe Merrill, Shaw Walters, Travis Oliphant
items.summary:
- The Open Source AI Foundation has initiated a US$10 million campaign to promote open-source AI.
- The campaign aims to influence lawmakers to prioritize transparency and auditability.
- The initiative is led by Brittany Kaiser and supported by advocates like Joe Merrill, Shaw Walters, and Travis Oliphant.
- Supporters highlight the need for transparency and trust in public-sector AI and urge reconsideration of contracts with closed-source providers.
- Critics raise concerns about the potential misuse of open systems due to oversight challenges.
- The foundation is seeking tech funding and remains open to collaboration with supporters of open-source AI.

items.title: OpenAI bans accounts possibly linked to N Korea job fraud
items.summary:
- OpenAI has banned accounts that may be connected to job fraud linked to North Korea.
- The action was taken to prevent misuse of the AI model for fraudulent purposes.
- This decision highlights ongoing concerns about cybersecurity and the potential for AI technology to be abused.

items.title: Indian hiring platform Apna cuts losses by 57% in FY24
items.summary:
- Apna reduced its net loss by over 57% in FY24 to 51.3 crore rupee (US$5.92 million) from 120.3 crore rupee in FY23.
- EBITDA loss decreased to 35.2 crore rupee (US$4.06 million), improving the EBITDA margin to -28% from -58%.
- Operating revenue fell by over 29% year-on-year to 127.6 crore rupee (US$14.73 million), mainly due to reduced income from software development services.
- Total revenue, including additional income, reached 139.8 crore rupee (US$16.13 million).
- Founded in 2019, Apna originally focused on blue- and grey-collar job listings and expanded to white-collar roles in 2021.

items.title: UAE self-storage firm The Box bags $12.5m debt funding
items.summary:
- Dubai-based self-storage provider The Box secured US$12.5 million in debt financing led by Shorooq Partners.
- The funds will aid in expansion and the development of a new storage facility in Dubai.
- Founded in 2007, The Box provides self-storage units, record management, and moving solutions throughout the UAE.
- The financing will help build a new facility to accommodate increasing demand.
- The Box holds a significant market share in the expanding UAE self-storage market driven by urban growth and a rising expatriate population.
- This funding fortifies its market position and addresses evolving consumer storage needs.

items.title: Israeli hydrogen firm seeks court protection over debt
items.summary:
- Electriq Global, an Israeli hydrogen technology startup, has filed for court protection due to nearly US$29.4 million in debt.
- The Haifa District Court has frozen proceedings and appointed Attorney Alona Baumgarten as a trustee for potential rehabilitation.
- Founded in 2013, Electriq Global specializes in hydrogen storage and has reduced its workforce from 30 to 6 employees due to financial troubles.
- A €25 million investment from a Dutch investor was frozen because of Israel's security situation.
- Employees reported unpaid salaries for January 2025, with February wages also at risk.
- The company aims to arrange a debt settlement and seek shareholder support, with court proceedings determining next steps.

items.title: These funds have not invested in China in the past year
items.summary:
- A list of funds that backed companies in China in the past two years but have not invested in the last 12 months is presented.
- The lack of investment could indicate various strategic reasons, such as waiting for better market conditions.
- Timing outreach to investors is emphasized as crucial for potential funding opportunities.

items.title: DeepSeek to open-source AI tech while OpenAI limits access
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI startup, will release open-source technology next week, providing access to five code repositories from its R1 platform.
- The company has gained attention for AI models that outperform OpenAI and Meta in benchmark tests.
- DeepSeek's initiative contrasts with OpenAI’s reduced open releases, aiming to promote wider adoption despite raising security concerns.
- Founder Liang Wenfeng has not disclosed any external funding sources, stating the company relies on parent and government funding.
- The resources shared by DeepSeek are tested, deployed, and well-documented, emphasizing transparency in AI research.

items.title: Google, Meta execs warn EU AI rules limit innovation
items.summary:
- Executives from Google and Meta criticized the European Union’s strict AI regulations at the Techarena tech conference in Stockholm.
- They argued that compliance requirements, including the GDPR and the proposed AI Act, are delaying innovation and product rollouts in Europe.
- Meta’s Chris Yiu cited challenges in launching AI-powered Ray-Ban Meta glasses, while Google DeepMind’s Dorothy Chou noted that the AI Act was drafted before key advancements like ChatGPT.
- The AI Act, proposed in 2021, aims to regulate AI within the EU, but major tech firms warn it could stifle growth.
- European venture capitalists called for simpler, more unified rules, suggesting a “28th regime” to streamline compliance and attract talent.
- Critics argue that the EU’s regulatory approach may hinder Europe’s technological progress.

items.title: Meta approves higher executive bonuses, up to 200% salary
items.summary:
- Meta has revised its bonus plan for executive officers to allow up to **200%** of their base salary in annual bonuses, increased from a **75%** cap.
- The board approved this change on **February 13** following a compensation review compared to peer companies.
- The changes do not apply to CEO **Mark Zuckerberg**.
- This decision follows layoffs affecting **5%** of Meta's workforce, with a focus on low performers, and a **10%** reduction in stock option distributions for many employees.

items.title: Southeast Asia insurtech funding drops 61% in 2024: report
items.summary:
- Insurtech funding in Southeast Asia fell 61% in 2024 to US$193 million from US$495 million in 2023.
- The decline is attributed to global economic challenges such as inflation and geopolitical uncertainties.
- Seed-stage funding decreased by 16% to US$7.7 million; early-stage investments dropped 80% to US$38.5 million.
- Late-stage funding increased by 11% to US$147 million, with Bolttech securing the largest deal at US$100 million.
- A funding rebound in H2 2024 reached US$111 million, a 35% increase from H1 but 50% lower than H2 2023.
- Singapore led funding with US$135 million, followed by Jakarta (US$50.5 million) and Kuala Lumpur (US$1.2 million).
- Acquisition activity slowed with only one deal recorded, compared to five in 2023.
- No new unicorns emerged for the second consecutive year.
- Despite the drop in funding, there are indications of potential recovery due to government initiatives and global interest.

items.title: Shopee, OpenAI team up to explore AI shopping tool in SEA
items.summary:
- Shopee collaborates with [OpenAI](https://www.techinasia.com/news/shopee-openai-team-explore-ai-shopping-tool-sea) to explore AI agents in Southeast Asia and Brazil.
- Shopee is the launch partner for OpenAI’s Operator, an AI agent for online shopping tasks.
- The AI tool is in research preview phase; user feedback will be gathered for refinement.

items.title: This VC looks deep into deeptech
items.author: Michael Gryseels
items.summary:
- Antares Ventures, led by Michael Gryseels, focuses on deeptech startups addressing major challenges in Southeast Asia and India.
- The firm is most interested in late seed to series B investments; series A is their sweet spot.
- Singapore’s deeptech funding hit a five-year low in 2024, leading the government to pledge US$324 million to attract more VC investments.
- Indian deeptech startup Probus raised US$5 million in a series A1 round to enhance energy management solutions.
- The article highlights a US$57.6 million fund launched by India for early-stage spacetech companies.

items.title: These are the most active investors in India’s startups
items.summary:
- The article provides a list of the most active investors in India’s startups over the past two years based on the number of deals.
- It focuses on firms that have invested in three or more companies in India within the last 12 months.
- The data is dynamically updated and aims to reflect the impact of each investment firm accurately, addressing any inaccuracies through user input.

items.title: Huawei, SAIC Motor partner for intelligent new EVs
items.summary:
- SAIC Motor partners with Huawei to develop electric intelligent vehicles.
- Collaboration includes manufacturing, supply chain management, and sales services.
- Strategic agreement aims to integrate automotive and technology sectors.

items.title: China expands AI education with DeepSeek
items.summary:
- Chinese universities are integrating AI courses utilizing technology from Hangzhou-based startup DeepSeek.
- Shenzhen University has launched an AI course featuring DeepSeek’s models, addressing crucial topics including security, privacy, and ethics.
- Other institutions like Zhejiang University, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, and Renmin University are also adopting DeepSeek’s AI for education and campus management.
- These initiatives align with China’s national action plan to establish a high-quality education system by 2035, released in January.

items.title: Microsoft prepares for GPT-4.5, GPT-5 launch
items.summary:
- Microsoft is preparing servers to host OpenAI’s GPT-4.5 and GPT-5.
- GPT-4.5, codenamed Orion, may launch in the coming weeks, with Microsoft ready as early as next week.
- GPT-5 will include significant updates with the integration of OpenAI's o3 reasoning model.

items.title: Xiaohongshu downloads drop as TikTok doubles on iPhone return
items.summary:
- TikTok's downloads more than doubled after being reinstated on Apple and Google stores.
- In contrast, rival app Xiaohongshu, also known as Rednote, experienced a 91% decline in downloads during the same period.
- Despite the drop in downloads, Xiaohongshu's daily active users remain about 25% higher than before TikTok's removal.

items.title: Estonia’s tech sector boosts defense startup growth
items.summary:
- Estonia and central/eastern European nations are increasing investments in defense tech following Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022.
- Estonia is utilizing its tech industry to support defense startups, capitalizing on its geographical proximity to Russia.
- European defense tech investments grew from 0.4% to 1.7% of total venture capital, amounting to nearly $1 billion between 2022 and 2024.
- Central and eastern Europe have seen a threefold increase in defense funding rounds since the conflict began.
- Estonia's position enables quick collaboration with front-line units and focuses on military tech in private ventures.

items.title: PhonePe begins preparations for IPO
items.summary:
- PhonePe has initiated preparations for its upcoming IPO.
- The company aims to capitalize on the growing fintech market in India.
- Further details regarding the IPO timeline and valuation are yet to be disclosed.

items.title: Temu expands data collection from Korean users
items.summary:
- Temu updates privacy policy for Korean users effective February 21.
- The platform now collects additional personal data such as addresses, phone numbers, transaction amounts, and personal customs clearance codes.
- Users must consent to sharing their data with 27 third-party companies across six countries, including Korea, the US, and Singapore.
- The update follows scrutiny over data collection practices by foreign tech companies in South Korea.
- Last year, investigations were launched into platforms like Temu and AliExpress, with AliExpress fined for privacy violations.
- A decision regarding Temu from Korea's Personal Information Protection Commission is expected soon.

items.title: Brazil fines X $1.4m for failing to share YouTuber’s data
items.summary:
- Brazil's Supreme Court fined X (formerly Twitter) 8.1 million reais (US$1.4 million) for not providing user data on a conservative YouTuber.
- The YouTuber was accused of threatening justices.
- X previously argued it does not collect registration data.
- X was also fined 50,000 reais (US$8,768) per day for failing to block the YouTuber's account and payment transfers.

items.title: Series SEA: Who’s investing in the region’s biotech startups?
items.summary:
- The article discusses the most active investors in Southeast Asia’s biotech sector over the past two years.
- It presents a list of firms arranged by the number of deals made in the region, focusing on those that invested in three or more startups.
- The data is continuously updated and aims to provide insights into the impact of each firm in the biotech investment landscape.
- Readers are encouraged to report any inaccuracies in the data by contacting the publisher.

items.title: CATL, Volkswagen partner on EV battery development
items.summary:
- CATL and Volkswagen signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on Feb. 20 for battery R&D.
- Focuses on new materials, component production, and cost-effective battery products.
- The partnership will also explore battery recycling and swapping initiatives.

items.title: Chinese bubble tea chain Mixue aims for $443m Hong Kong IPO
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Mixue Group plans to raise HK$3.45 billion (approximately US$443.66 million) through an IPO in Hong Kong.
- The company will offer 17.1 million shares at HK$202.5 each.
- Bookbuilding for the IPO started on February 21, with trading beginning on March 3.
- Founded in 1997 by Zhang Hongchao, Mixue operates 45,000 stores domestically and in 11 other countries.

items.title: US healthtech AI startup OpenEvidence bags $75m
items.summary:
- OpenEvidence, a Massachusetts-based AI healthcare startup, raised US$75 million in a funding round led by Sequoia Capital, reaching a valuation of US$1 billion.
- This is the startup's first institutional funding since it was founded in 2021.
- The startup has developed a chatbot to assist physicians, currently used by a quarter of US doctors, that is trained exclusively on peer-reviewed medical journals.
- The funds will be used for strategic partnerships and to expand adoption in the healthcare sector.
- OpenEvidence offers its chatbot for free and generates revenue through advertising.
- Founder Daniel Nadler stated the mission is to reduce physician burnout and address healthcare system shortages.

items.title: Billionaire Ryan Cohen raises stake in Alibaba to $1b
items.summary:
- Billionaire investor Ryan Cohen increases his stake in Alibaba to approximately US$1 billion, owning around 7 million shares.
- Cohen first invested in Alibaba in early 2023 and has advocated for share buybacks while discussing a potential long-term partnership.
- Alibaba's US-listed shares surged up to 15% after the news, closing over 8% higher, contributing to a 60% gain this year.
